title: Can Schumer and McConnell just get along?
content:
Mitch McConnell remembers Chuck Schumer ’ s role during his contentious 2008 campaign like it was yesterday .
In the home stretch of the election season , the Schumer-led Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee launched blistering TV ads accusing the Republican leader of inducing the economic meltdown with lax regulations and then bailing out Wall Street . McConnell was infuriated . He believed the attacks breached a pact by the two parties not to politicize the government rescue in the elections , something Democrats disputed .
“ I don ’ t think any hatchet needed to be buried , ” McConnell said when asked in a recent interview whether he had made peace with Schumer . “ I won , he lost . ”
“ They tried again last year . I won , they lost overwhelmingly , ” he added . “ I don ’ t get mad about it . I don ’ t own the seat . They want to have a contest , we have a contest . ”
McConnell , now the Senate majority leader , and Schumer , the Democratic leader-in-waiting , will now have to figure out how — and when — to drop their political swords . Despite serving 16 years together in the chamber , the two men have developed virtually no rapport in a body where trust and relationships are essential . To the extent they ’ ve engaged , it ’ s mainly been to launch political — and at times , personal — attacks .
But with Schumer set to replace Sen. Harry Reid as Democratic leader in the next Congress , the New York Democrat and the Kentucky Republican will soon have to work with each other on a daily basis — on issues as mundane as the Senate schedule and as profound as the country ’ s domestic and foreign policy . Their relationship could go a long way in deciding how much of the next president ’ s campaign agenda gets done , since neither party is likely to have a filibuster-proof majority .
“ They both enjoy political mischief and are good at it , ” said Sen. Lamar Alexander ( R-Tenn. ) , who is close to both men . “ But if they can keep the political mischief down to about 25 percent of what they do , I think they have a very good chance to be awfully good Senate leaders working together . ”
But the lack of affection between the two men is evident . Just last week each accused the other of causing the latest round of Senate gridlock . At the same time , they ’ re both relatively nonideological pragmatists who , when it comes down to it , want to make a deal . That bodes well for future productivity , fellow senators from both parties said .
“ Schumer is kind of transactional and kind of a dealmaker and likes to , I think , get things done . Sen. McConnell obviously likes to get things done , ” said Sen. John Thune ( R-S.D . ) , the No . 3 in his party ’ s leadership . “ So if you can find the common ground , there may be the foundation of some success . ”
“ I think he ’ ll be fine , ” Reid said of Schumer ’ s ability to work with McConnell . “ Chuck is somebody that certainly understands what ’ s going on around here ; he ’ s been included in things I ’ ve done for a number of years now . He ’ ll do very well . ”
The two men could hardly be more different in how they operate . The 64-year-old Schumer charges through the Senate , speaking loudly on his flip phone and keeping his finger on the pulse of a range of issues . He schmoozes with his colleagues at the Senate gym and rubs elbows with them over wine and cheese on the first floor of the chamber .
The 73-year-old McConnell is laconic , reserved and calculating . He rarely tips his hand on his next step and spends little time worrying whether his colleagues find him personally charming .
“ Mitch can be implacable , and it ’ s going to be hard for anybody to change that , ” said Sen. Sheldon Whitehouse ( D-R.I. ) , who is close to Schumer . He added , “ I suppose if there ’ s a way , Chuck is the person most likely to find it . ”
Schumer emerged as Reid ’ s heir apparent immediately after the Nevadan ’ s retirement announcement in March , yet Schumer and McConnell have yet to speak much since . McConnell still works primarily with Reid , and Schumer , who declined to be interviewed for this article , wants to avoid looking like he ’ s prematurely preparing to take over . Reid still has a year and a half in office .
Republicans have grown increasingly frustrated with Reid and are optimistic that the Senate will function better with Schumer as Democratic leader . But the New Yorker will face enormous challenges . At the top of the list : managing the needs of red-state Democrats , including several who ’ ll be up for reelection in states like North Dakota and Missouri , with an ascendant progressive wing led by Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren .
Then there ’ s the touchy task of filling out his leadership team . Schumer has yet to make key decisions about his top lieutenants , including whether to push for the current Democratic whip , Dick Durbin of Illinois , to stay in that position . The two have had a tense relationship , but Durbin repeated in an interview that he has the votes to remain in the job .
Durbin could , however , face a challenge from Sen. Patty Murray ( D-Wash. ) , who has been close with Schumer . She ’ s avoided discussing her ambitions within the caucus since Reid ’ s announcement .
While Durbin said Schumer ’ s deal-making skills during the 2013 immigration debate show he can work with Republicans , it ’ s an open question how he handles the wily McConnell .
“ It remains to be seen , ” Durbin said . “ Each leader has his own chemistry . Same is obviously true for Chuck Schumer and Mitch McConnell . And we will see . ”
For many years , Reid and McConnell had a trusting relationship . Each had methodically risen through the ranks of his caucus , and each eventually served as his party ’ s whip before both became elected as leaders .
But in the past Congress , their relationship deteriorated , according to senators and aides . McConnell and Reid viewed each other as breaking the customs of an institution both revered . The ill will grew in 2013 , when Reid took the unprecedented step of changing filibuster rules to overcome GOP stalling tactics on presidential nominations . It became more contentious as the Democratic leader sought to defeat McConnell in his hard-fought reelection contest in 2014 .
Things grew so frosty that McConnell and Reid would occasionally rely on emissaries to communicate . Schumer would speak with one of McConnell ’ s chief deputies , like Alexander or Senate Republican Whip John Cornyn , to trade intelligence .
“ I think it would be a fresh start for that relationship , ” Cornyn said of Schumer and McConnell . “ Reid and McConnell , I think , have obviously had to deal with each other , and it ’ s been a challenging relationship . ”
McConnell ’ s aides say that the GOP leader doesn ’ t get hung up on personalities and is willing to work with just about anyone . Case in point : McConnell didn ’ t have much of a relationship with Joe Biden in the Senate , yet the senator and the vice president struck some of the most consequential fiscal deals during the Obama presidency .
In recent days , McConnell and Schumer have ratcheted up their barbs as action has stalled on a range of matters , from appropriations to defense spending . McConnell accused Democratic leaders of wanting to “ paint ” their offices and “ fatten ” the IRS instead of fund military equipment and give pay raises to troops .
“ When Sen. McConnell tries to go at it alone , he fails and fails inevitably , ” Schumer told reporters last week . “ When he tries to work with the other side , which hasn ’ t happened enough , he gets something done , plain and simple . ”
The sniping isn ’ t new . After the 2010 election , when Schumer was elevated to be the Democrats ’ main messaging man , the two were frequently at each other ’ s throats .
Part of it also stemmed from the nasty 2008 campaign . McConnell later said the Wall Street attacks were “ beyond the pale ” since Schumer and other party leaders agreed not to use the bailout as political fodder in the election .
It took them more than two years to discuss the matter . During a negotiation over Senate rules in 2011 , Schumer informed McConnell he wasn ’ t responsible for the content of the ads .
McConnell said he has moved on . But that doesn ’ t mean he ’ s forgotten .
“ Their relationship suffered , ” Alexander said , “ and Sen. McConnell has a long memory . ”
Still , Alexander added , “ I see no reason why they can ’ t have the kind of relationship that Senate leaders usually have , which is , No . 1 , to respect the institution . ”
